definition: A security that represents ownership in a company. Shareholders own a piece of the company.
A single unit of stock. If you own 10 shares of AAPL, you own 10 units of Apple’s stock.
A portion of a company's profits paid to shareholders, usually quarterly.
A market condition where prices are rising or expected to rise.
A market condition where prices are falling or expected to fall.
The first time a company offers its stock to the public.
A collection of securities traded on an exchange like a stock. Often tracks an index.
A pool of money from investors managed by professionals to invest in securities.
The total value of a company’s outstanding shares: price × number of shares.
Shares of large, stable, reputable companies with a history of performance.
A measure of how much a stock’s price fluctuates over time.
A collection of financial assets like stocks, bonds, ETFs owned by an investor.
An investor's ability and willingness to endure losses in their portfolio.
Stock price divided by earnings per share. High P/E may mean overvaluation.
A company’s net profit divided by its number of outstanding shares.
Income (like dividends or interest) received from an investment, expressed as a % of price.
How easily an asset can be converted into cash without affecting its price.
A person or platform that facilitates buying and selling of financial securities.
Instructions to buy or sell a stock, like market order, limit order, or stop-loss.
A benchmark representing a section of the market (e.g. S&P 500, Nasdaq-100).
